vocabulary.english: enclitic particle that means already or now
enclitic particle that means yet, still or else
enclitic particle that means only or just
enclitic particle that contrasts or enlivens
enclitic particle that indicates a question

contents.markdown: Earlier in the book you were given an introduction to enclitics, and told that eventually there would be a lesson that covers them more thoroughly. This is that lesson. First read **Appendix J**, which contains a re-cap and general information about all enclitics. Although there are 21 enclitic particles in all, we are only going to use the nine listed above, the most common ones, in enclitic clusters from here on. Two more will be introduced later. That should get you used to them without overwhelming you. After that, you should be able to pick up new ones when you encounter them.

In this lesson we will introduce _pa, din/rin_ and_ lang_._ Nga, po _and_ ba _were covered sufficiently in previous lessons, but additional information for_ na_ and _naman_ is given below. Finally, you will practice building sentences with all nine.

One thing you will notice below is that there are often multiple translations for each enclitic particle, and combinations may lead to unexpected results. The definitions given in the vocabulary list above are overly simplified – they are just there as memory hooks.
<u>Na and Pa</u>

_Na_ and _pa_ are related, and they both indicate that the sentence contains new information. But _na_ indicates information that is completely new, while _pa_ indicates new information that continues from previous events.

item.english: She is a teacher now. She was not a teacher before but she is now.
She is still a teacher. She was a teacher before and continues to be one.
She is not a teacher anymore. She was a teacher before but now she is not.
She is not a teacher yet. She was not a teacher before and continues not to be one.
Go study now. You were not studying before but I want you to study now.
Study some more. You were already studying but I want you to study more.

contents.markdown: <u>Din/Rin</u>
In its simplest contexts, _din/rin_ adds the nuance of “also”.

item.english: She is also a teacher.

contents.markdown: But _din/rin_ can also intensify certain other enclitic particles, such as _pa_.

item.english: She is still a teacher. She has been a teacher for a while and was expected to not be one anymore at some point but the situation persists.
She is still not a teacher. We have been waiting for her to become one for a while, but she still is not one.
Study some more. You have already been studying but finals are coming up and I fear you are not yet prepared.

contents.markdown: Notice that this intensification does not occur with na.

item.english: She is also a teacher now.
She is not a teacher now either.
Go study now too.

contents.markdown: <u>Lang</u>
_Lamang_ is the formal version of _lang_, and is far less common, so we will not use it from now on. _Lang_ normally adds the nuance of “only” or “just”.

item.english: She is only a teacher.
She is not only a teacher.
Just study.

contents.markdown: In addition to the expected nuance of “just” or “now just”, _na lang_ can also be used to confirm a choice.

item.english: She is just a teacher. She had additional work before, but now she is just a teacher.
Just study.
Chocolate. You were asked if you want chocolate or vanilla.

contents.markdown: <u>Naman</u>
As mentioned before, although _naman_ is often interchangeable with _nga_, we will not use it to soften sentences in order to keep it separate from _nga_.
It can also be used to show contrast.

item.tagalog: Naglalaro si Maria sa eskwelahan, ako naman sa kalsada.
item.english: Maria plays at school, whereas I play in the street.
I will drive (for a change).
(in contrast) She is not pretty.

contents.markdown: And it can enliven a sentence by showing energy, irritation, disgust, etc.

item.english: Yeah, for sure!
Drive already!
It is absolutely true!

contents.markdown: <u>Some Enclitic Particles can give sentences multiple Meanings.</u>
Most enclitic particles apply to the entire clause, but _din/rin, lang_ and_ naman_(contrast) do not, which may make you wonder what a sentence actually means. Let’s take:

item.english: She also studied Tagalog.

contents.markdown: Does this mean “she studied and listened to it” (applied to verb), “she studied Tagalog and French” (applied to the object) or “she and her friend studied Tagalog” (applied to the focus)? It turns out the first two interpretations are ok, but not the third. In this book we call these “focus sensitive” enclitic particles, and they do not apply to the focus of standard sentences. Here are a couple more examples:

item.english: They are only opening the door.

contents.markdown: “Only” does not apply to “door” here. For example, this can mean they are only opening it and not slamming it, or only they are opening it and not Joe, but it cannot mean only the door and not the window.

item.tagalog: Tuturuan naman ni Vanessa ang mga estudyante.
item.english: In contrast, Vanessa will teach the students.

contents.markdown: “In contrast” does not apply to “students” here. For example, this can mean in contrast to singing with them, she will teach them, or in contrast to Joshua, Vanessa will teach them. But it cannot mean in contrast to the parents she will teach the students.

Notice that if you emphasize the focus while reading the English sentences above, it seems like “also/only/in contrast” should apply to the focus. But it does not. This is an example of how focus differs from emphasis. We will discuss ways to apply these enclitic particles to focuses in a later lesson.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pagod din ang anak natin, di ba?
exampleSentences.english: Our (incl.) child is also tired, isn't he?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ang mga ito lang ba ang mga sikat nilang puting sapatos?
exampleSentences.english: Are these their only famous white shoes?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Magtuturo pa naman si Sir Santos ng Tagalog sa Sabado.
exampleSentences.english: In contrast, Mr. Santos will still teach Tagalog on Saturday.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ano naman po ang inuming yun?
exampleSentences.english: What (on the other hand) is that drink? (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Mahilig ka pa ba sa ilaw?
Buksan nga rin po ninyo ang pinto nang pitong oras para sa akin.
exampleSentences.english: Open the door for me for seven hours too. (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi ko lang binigyan ng pera si Joe.
exampleSentences.english: I did not only give Joe money.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Gusto lang naman namin ang sandaang piso!
exampleSentences.english: We (excl.) only want one hundred pesos! (irritated)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sinusubukan pa niya ang bawat basketbol nang maraming beses.
exampleSentences.english: He still tries each basketball many times.
